passage_list.text: Gwendolen wears the diamonds, and from then on dreams daily of an escape from her life that can be achieved only through death, either hers or his; soon enough she cares not which. The problem is solved when Eliot has Grandcourt fall off a boat while on holiday and allows Gwendolen to watch, mesmerized, as he drowns, begging her to throw him a rope. She is twenty-two years old; her life is over.

Put on the diamonds. For years, I could hear the menace in Grandcourt’s voice whenever I saw or felt a woman struggling to break free of a despotic husband or lover. The piteousness of her position—that of one born to sanctioned subordination—always seemed emblematic to me of all the sadism allowed to flourish in intimate relations, doomed to end one fine day with a twist in the brain that can no longer bow beneath the yoke.

The tales of harassment in the workplace that surfaced when the #MeToo movement erupted in 2017 made my head swim, so wide-ranging were the accusations. From an arm rub and comment about a sexy dress to physical assault, they revealed behaviors that were simultaneously condoned as acceptable and experienced as denigrating. Among these tales I found particularly haunting precisely the homeliest examples of the sort of sexual offenses that have been shrugged off for generations, those that typified the instrumental use men and women commonly make of one another.

I imagine a woman walking into her office every workday for years, her throat tight, her stomach in knots, ready to swallow the dose of medicine she has to down if she is to hold this job. She speaks of this vile ritual to no one because she knows the men would laugh and the women roll their eyes, so commonplace is her complaint, but day by day, month by year, it feels as though something vital in her is eroding: some sense of personhood she was becoming aware of at exactly the moment she felt she might be losing it. It is the helplessness of her position that gnaws at her—the shock of realizing she has no agency in a culture that accepts as normal that which she experiences as degrading.

In 2017, when such women were coming out of the woodwork, their faces contorted with rage, their voices hissing and spitting, sending out a tsunami of resentment that threatened to drown all of us—women and men alike—they were demonstrating that if the insults go too long unaddressed, they might one day bring down a civilization.

Why does it hurt so much, do so much damage, twist us so horribly out of shape? Why does life seem unbearable—yes, unbearable—if we feel discounted in our own eyes? Or perhaps a better way to pose the question is to turn it around and ask, as a wise woman I know once did, Why do we need to think well of ourselves? Ah yes, I thought, when she put it that way, why is it not enough to be fed, clothed, and sheltered, given freedom of speech and movement? Why do we also have to think well of ourselves?

The question haunts every culture: no matter who, no matter where, we crave an explanation for why we are as we are; we manufacture bodies of thought and faith, century after century, that hold out the promise of an explanation that will assuage if not our suffering, at least our brooding. Sigmund Freud, whose analytic thought concentrated on curing us of the inner divisions that make us vulnerable to self-hatred, hit upon an explanation that for the longest time offered the greatest hope; out of his empathic imagination arose the therapeutic culture, armed with its encyclopedia of theories designed to address the dilemma.

Psychoanalysis explains that from the moment we are born we crave recognition. We open our eyes and we want a response. We need to be warm and dry, yes, soothed and caressed, but even more we need to be looked upon with interest and affection, as though we are a thing of value. Routinely, we get only some small amount of what we need, and sometimes we don’t get it at all. The emotional conviction that we are not worthy sets in. From this condition none of us ever wholly recovers. Mainly, our feelings go underground and we struggle on, in general doing to others no more harm than was done to us. Some of us, however—starting with those born into the wrong class or sex or race, or perhaps those whose physical appearance leads to mockery or rejection—are so damaged we obsess over being made to not think well of ourselves, and we become dangerously antisocial. The effort to overcome this primitive state of affairs is what preoccupies analysis, but all too often the endeavor drags on and on (and on!) while our demons refuse to relent; then therapy begins to feel like a romantic hope of salvation destined to fail.

In the 1940s, the social psychologist Erich Fromm asked the same question—in essence, why we succumb so readily to humiliation—and arrived at a place some distance, but not a great one, from that of Freud. Fromm’s thesis in his great work, Escape from Freedom, was a simple one; like Freud before him, Fromm did not hesitate to use the convention of mythic storytelling to make his insight vivid for the common reader.

In Freud’s case the story derived from the classics; in Fromm’s, from Genesis. Human beings, he argued, were at one with nature until they ate from the Tree of Knowledge, whereupon they evolved into animals endowed with the ability to reason and to know that they felt. From then on, they were creatures apart, no longer at one with the universe they had long inhabited on an equal basis with other dumb animals. For the human race, the gift of thought and emotion created both the glory of independence and the punishment of isolation; on one hand, the dichotomy made us proud; on the other, lonely. It was the loneliness that proved our undoing. It became our punishment of punishments. It so perverted our instincts that we became strangers to ourselves—the true meaning of alienation—and thus unable to feel kinship with others. Which, of course, made us even lonelier. The inability to connect brought on guilt and shame: terrible guilt, outsized shame, shame that gradually developed into humiliation. If there was any stigma that survived the exile from paradise—that is, the womb—any proof that we were unfitted to make a success of life, it was this. How else to explain all the centuries in which human beings have been mortally ashamed of admitting they were lonely?

questions.question: What is the central idea of the passage?
questions.explanation: The passage focuses on Gwendolen's internal struggle and her despair, which is central to the narrative.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Focus on the emotional and psychological aspects of the characters to identify the central idea.

questions.question: As used in the passage, 'sanctioned subordination' most nearly means:
questions.explanation: The phrase 'sanctioned subordination' implies a form of inferiority that is socially or culturally approved.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for contextual clues that explain the relationship between the words and their implications.

questions.question: The author suggests that the #MeToo movement revealed what about workplace harassment?

options.A: It was more widespread than previously thought
options.B: It was often exaggerated by the media
options.C: It was primarily physical in nature
options.D: It was less severe than historical accounts suggest

questions.explanation: The passage indicates that the accusations were wide-ranging, suggesting that harassment was more pervasive than previously acknowledged.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Inference questions require you to read between the lines and understand the implications of the text.

questions.question: The author's description of the woman's daily routine serves primarily to:

options.B: Illustrate the emotional toll of her situation

questions.explanation: The detailed description emphasizes the emotional and psychological impact of her daily struggles.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Pay attention to how the author uses descriptive details to convey deeper meanings.

questions.question: The author uses the phrase 'tsunami of resentment' to emphasize:

options.A: The overwhelming nature of the women's anger
options.B: The destructive power of natural disasters

questions.explanation: The metaphor 'tsunami of resentment' underscores the intensity and scale of the women's collective anger.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Metaphors and similes are often used to highlight the intensity or scale of emotions or events.

questions.question: Which choice best supports the idea that self-worth is a fundamental human need?

options.A: Why does it hurt so much, do so much damage, twist us so horribly out of shape?
options.B: Why do we need to think well of ourselves?
options.C: Why is it not enough to be fed, clothed, and sheltered?
options.D: Why do we also have to think well of ourselves?

questions.explanation: The question 'Why do we also have to think well of ourselves?' directly addresses the necessity of self-worth.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for direct statements or questions that address the core idea being asked about.

questions.question: The author's reference to Sigmund Freud primarily serves to:

options.B: Provide a historical context for psychological thought
options.D: Introduce a framework for understanding human behavior

questions.explanation: Freud's theories are introduced as a way to understand the human need for recognition and the origins of self-hatred.
questions.score_improvement_tip: References to other thinkers or theories often serve to provide a framework or context for the author's argument.

questions.question: Which choice best completes the sentence? 'The emotional conviction that we are not worthy sets in. From this condition none of us ever wholly recovers. Mainly, our feelings go underground and we struggle on, in general doing to others no more harm than was done to us. Some of us, however—starting with those born into the wrong class or sex or race, or perhaps those whose physical appearance leads to mockery or rejection—are so damaged we obsess over being made to not think well of ourselves, and we become dangerously antisocial.'

options.A: The effort to overcome this primitive state of affairs is what preoccupies analysis, but all too often the endeavor drags on and on (and on!) while our demons refuse to relent; then therapy begins to feel like a romantic hope of salvation destined to fail.
options.B: The effort to overcome this primitive state of affairs is what preoccupies analysis, but all too often the endeavor drags on and on (and on!) while our demons refuse to relent, then therapy begins to feel like a romantic hope of salvation destined to fail.
options.C: The effort to overcome this primitive state of affairs is what preoccupies analysis, but all too often the endeavor drags on and on (and on!) while our demons refuse to relent. Then therapy begins to feel like a romantic hope of salvation destined to fail.
options.D: The effort to overcome this primitive state of affairs is what preoccupies analysis, but all too often the endeavor drags on and on (and on!) while our demons refuse to relent; then, therapy begins to feel like a romantic hope of salvation destined to fail.

questions.explanation: The correct choice uses proper punctuation to separate the two independent clauses, making the sentence clear and grammatically correct.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Pay attention to the use of semicolons and periods to separate independent clauses correctly.

questions.question: The author suggests that Erich Fromm's work is similar to Freud's in that both:

options.A: Use mythic storytelling to explain psychological concepts
options.B: Focus on the role of loneliness in human behavior
options.D: Emphasize the importance of social class in shaping identity

questions.explanation: Both Freud and Fromm use mythic storytelling to make their psychological insights accessible to readers.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for similarities in the methods or approaches used by different thinkers discussed in the text.

questions.question: As used in the passage, 'alienation' most nearly means:
questions.explanation: The term 'alienation' in this context encompasses feelings of isolation, estrangement, and disconnection.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When a word has multiple meanings, consider the context to determine which meanings are relevant.

scoring_guidelines.800_level_performance: Students scoring at this level demonstrate mastery of all tested skills, including advanced analysis, synthesis, and reasoning. They can interpret complex texts, make nuanced inferences, and understand subtle rhetorical strategies.
scoring_guidelines.700_level_performance: Students scoring at this level show strong comprehension and reasoning skills but may struggle with higher-level analysis and synthesis. They can identify main ideas and details but may miss subtler implications or connections.

explanation_summary.hard_questions: Hard questions test advanced analytical and reasoning skills, often requiring students to infer meaning, analyze complex text structures, or understand nuanced rhetorical strategies.
explanation_summary.medium_questions: Medium questions assess comprehension and vocabulary in context, with a focus on understanding main ideas, details, and the author's purpose.
explanation_summary.easy_questions: Easy questions evaluate basic comprehension and the ability to identify explicit information in the text, such as central ideas or straightforward details.
